Issues.Title: Enhance the @Injectable annotation to allow developers to configure a string based name that can be used to load the object
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Ng 6 added the 'providedIn' property to the @Innjectable annotation which removes the need to explicitly list the injectable in a Module. However in some instances a developer may want to load the object through a name reference rather than a type reference so as to facilitate "Interface" based DI. In Spring IoC a object can be wired based on Type or Name. It would be handy to do the same in Ng in conjuction with the 'provideIn' property. Currently the only way to do this is by registering 2 providers for the same Injectable.

```
@NgModule( {
    imports: [
    ],
    providers: [
        AppUserApiService,
        { provide: 'AppUserApiService', useExisting: AppUserApiService },
    ]
}
```
Registering an injectable as above allows you to get a reference to the Injector object and retreieve the service by name,
```
let objectApiService : IAbstractService = this.injector.get('AppUserApiService ');
```
### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If we added a new property called "name" to the @Injectable annotation that would tell the DI system to define a second string based reference to the injectable then we would do away with the need to define that second reference explicitly in a module .

```
@Injectable(
providedIn:'XXX',
name:'AppUserApiService'
)
export class AppUserApiService extends IAbstractService<AppUser> {
}
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> 
The ability to provide a second  configuration for a injectable service is available but requires explicit registration in a module. Using the provideIn property excludes the ability to reference the Injectable by name.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enhance the @Injectable annotation to allow developers to configure a string based name that can be used to load the object" (#36848)

Issues.Title: build: update setup-rbe.sh script to accept non google.com/angular.io
Issues.Body:
Previously the setup-rbe.sh script did not allow accounts that did
have domains of angular.io or google.com.  Since we add emails from
other domains into everyone@angular.io, we are unable to be certain
in the script that the account is not actually a member of the
required group.  This change adds the option to choose to continue
with an email account logged in which we cannot verify by domain.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: update setup-rbe.sh script to accept non google.com/angular.io" (#36846)

Issues.Title: Format/Lint bazel via ng-dev format
Issues.Body:
See individual commits for details

___

Beginning with #36842 the previous `yarn bazel:*` commands are no longer used for formatting bazel related files across the repo. Instead this task is now performed using the ng-dev command. The formatting enforced and performed is identical and does not result in any change to the source code of the repository.

This is being done to streamline the commands and usages for running formatting and linting in the repository.

As we no longer rely on the yarn commands, if they are called a deprecation message will be returned.

Usage changes:
`yarn bazel:format` -> `yarn ng-dev format all`
`yarn bazel:lint-fix` -> `yarn ng-dev format all`
`yarn bazel:lint` -> `yarn ng-dev format all --check`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Format/Lint bazel via ng-dev format" (#36842)

Issues.Title: Is it possible to publish Angular 9 ivy compiled library.
Issues.Body:
I have upgraded by angular components library for **version 8 to version 9**. Since version 9 comes with ivy compilation by deafult, when I try to publish my library to npm repo. It gives me the following error:
**node --eval "console.error('ERROR: Trying to publish a package that has been compiled by Ivy. This is not allowed.\nPlease delete and rebuild the package, without compiling with Ivy, before attempting to publish.\n')" && exit 1**

Is there any workaround or the issue is expected in this version of angular since the official docs of angular says it is not recommended.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is it possible to publish Angular 9 ivy compiled library." (#36836)

Issues.Title: zone.js is not loadable as an AMD library
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package

zone.js


### Is this a regression?

No. The bug was introduced in 0.7.0 when zone.js switched from a CJS build to a UMD build. The behavior was broken in 0.7.0, but did not exist in 0.6. It continues to be broken in the latest builds of zone.js.

### Description

zone.js is published as a UMD module, but does not correctly call `define()` when in an AMD environment.

The [AMD spec](https://github.com/amdjs/amdjs-api) defines the behavior of AMD modules. The UMD module format is a wrapper around AMD that checks whether a library is running in an AMD-compatible environment (with `window.define` present). If in such an environment, it calls `define(factory)`.

The AMD spec calls for a module's [factory function](https://github.com/amdjs/amdjs-api/blob/master/AMD.md#factory-) to provide a value for the module. This can be done in one of two ways:

1. The factory function is given an `exports` object, which it modifies with the modules exports. [spec](https://github.com/amdjs/amdjs-api/blob/master/AMD.md#using-require-and-exports)
2. The factory function may return a value, which is used as the AMD module. [spec](https://github.com/amdjs/amdjs-api/blob/master/AMD.md#factory-)

**zone.js does neither of those things**, which results in AMD loaders not having the ZoneJS module available as an export.

"*But zone.js is always a global variable - it should never be used as an AMD module*"

I agree that ZoneJS should always create a global variable. However, by bundling to UMD it is saying that it is also a valid AMD module. As such, it should follow the AMD spec by providing that global variable as the exported value of its AMD module.

Two options to fix:

1. Change zone.js to not compile to UMD, but to iife. This can be done with rollup's `output.format` option.
2. Change zone.js to properly invoke `define()` as an AMD module, by returning the Zone function from its `factory` function

^ Either option would be great

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/s/serverless-dawn-lotul?file=/index.html

## üî• Exception or Error

`TypeError: Cannot read property 'subscribe' of undefined`

Original discussion about the error: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53466406/angular-7-ssr-problems-with-ngzone

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**
zone.js@0.10.3
Angular versions irrelevant, since Angular is not required to demonstrate this bug

**Anything else relevant?**
Applies to any browser and any AMD loader (not just SystemJS)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "zone.js is not loadable as an AMD library" (#36827)

Issues.Title: feat(compiler): add name spans for property reads and method calls
Issues.Body:
ASTs for property read and method calls contain information about
the entire span of the expression, including its receiver. Use cases
like a language service and compile error messages may be more
interested in the span of the direct identifier for which the
expression is constructed (i.e. an accessed property). To support this,
this commit adds a `nameSpan` property on

- `PropertyRead`s
- `SafePropertyRead`s
- `PropertyWrite`s
- `MethodCall`s
- `SafeMethodCall`s

The `nameSpan` property already existed for `BindingPipe`s.

This commit also updates usages of these expressions' `sourceSpan`s in
Ngtsc and the langauge service to use `nameSpan`s where appropriate.

Issues.Title: Assert all `Observables` unsubscribed
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for `@angular/core` (specifically `TestBed`).

### Description
It is very easy for developers to forget to unsubscribe to an `Observable`. Most commonly, developers may use `ngOnInit()` to subscribe to an `Observable`, but they should also unsubscribe in `ngOnDestory()`. If they forget to do this, they will not receive any error in testing or at runtime, but will have a potential memory leak and use unnecessary resources.

### Describe the solution you'd like
The two solutions I can think of, include:

* A conformance test for all components to assert that after the component is destroyed, there should not be any active `Observable` subscriptions.
    * `TestBed.configureTestingModule()` could perhaps add this assertion to the end of all tests? Or maybe some other `addAngularConformanceTests()` could be added somewhere in the test file.
    * This way, everyone implicitly tests for this invariant without thinking about it.
    * Downside is that this only really works for components.
* Some kind of `expectNoActiveSubscriptions();`
    * This would allow users to test services and other non-component code.
    * Users must manually add this assertion and remember to test for it.
    * Not sure the best way of pointing the user to the offending `Observable`. Maybe some O(n) check for the class under test (or all injectable objects) to see if the `Observable` is still referenced somewhere?

I'm not sure the best way of actually implementing either of these. The only way I can think of is spying on `Observable.prototype.subscribe()` and `Observable.prototype.unsubscribe()`, which is a pretty hacky solution to the problem. It might be worth a FR to RxJS to support this use case more explicitly.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
I think the current workaround is to spy on `Observable.prototype.{,un}subscribe()` manually. I think https://github.com/awerlang/observable-profiler can do this, though it requires more work for the user.

### Links to users asking for this feature
[b/155107643](http://b/155107643)
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54588424/how-to-test-is-all-subscription-unsubscribed-in-angular
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52364687/how-do-i-unit-test-unsubscribe-in-angular-and-jasmine
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Assert all `Observables` unsubscribed" (#36824)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): deprecate `WrappedValue`
Issues.Body:
The purpose of the `WrappedValue` is to allow same object instance to be treated as different for the purposes of change detection. It is currently used with `async` pipe and only with `Observables`. The use case which it covers is if the `Observable` produces the same instance of the value but it is desirable to still try to mark it as changed for the purposes of change detection.

We believe tha the above use case is too rare to warrant special handling in the framework. (Having special handling causes application slowdown for the users and mental load for the developers.) No replacement is planned for this deprecation.

##### Chore & Maintenance

##### Performance

-   `[jest-resolve]` Update `resolve` to a version using native `realpath`, which is faster than the default JS implementation ([#​9872](https://togithub.com/facebook/jest/pull/9872))

-   `[jest-runtime]` Add `teardown` method to clear any caches when tests complete ([#​9906](https://togithub.com/facebook/jest/pull/9906))
-   `[jest-runtime]` Do not pass files required internally through transformation when loading them ([#​9900](https://togithub.com/facebook/jest/pull/9900))

Issues.Title: Migration to v9: Don‚Äôt set compilerOptions.module to "esnext" if it is set to "commonjs"
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description During the migration from 8 to 9 the `compilerOptions.module` in `tsconfig.app.json` gets set to `esnext` because of #16094 As far as i understand #16094 should work with `esnext` but also with `commonjs`. I had `commonjs` before and it was unnecessarily overwritten. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Set `compilerOptions.module` in `tsconfig.app.json` to `commonjs`. Then run `ng update @angular/cli @angular/core`. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Errors in child compilers not reported, process exits without info
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... no ### Description If a compilation includes child compilations as is the case when using worker-loader for example (or many other webpack loaders/plugins) the build process can fail and exit without providing any info but the exit code being 1. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction clone [this](https://github.com/nadavsinai/angular-child-compiler-error), run ng build, no errors will be shown except of non-0 exit code or "failed to compile" in serve mode. anything with a child compiler emits errors into it's own errors object. you code in [createBrowserLoggingCallback](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/8.2.x/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/browser/index.ts#L71) which delegates to (stats.hasErrors() does not take into account the possibility of errors in child compilers. ## üî• Exception or Error 



the problem is the the error is not shown ;-)

Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [puppeteer](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer) | devDependencies | major | [`2.1.1` -> `3.0.2`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/puppeteer/2.1.1/3.0.2) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>puppeteer/puppeteer</summary>

### [`v3.0.2`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v3.0.2)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/compare/v3.0.1...v3.0.2)

### Highlights

-   `uploadFile` now throws for non-existent files ([#​5733](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5733))
-   Puppeteer currently fails to extract Chromium when installing on Node 14 (see tracking bug: [#​5719](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5719)). We now detect if you're on Node 14 and log a helpful error ([#​5732](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5732)).

### Behind the scenes

-   Many more files have been migrated to TypeScript and we're continuing with the goal of the `src` directory being 100% TypeScript.

### [`v3.0.1`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v3.0.1)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/compare/v3.0.0...v3.0.1)

### Highlights

-   File uploads should be more reliable now ([#​5655](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5655))
-   The size of the final package is smaller as we explicitly list files to publish ([#​5659](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5659)).
-   The docs now include the `libgbm-dev` dependency that's needed for Linux builds ([#​5667](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5667), [#​5693](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5693))

### Behind the scenes

-   We're continuing to migrate to TypeScript and many files within `src/` are now TypeScript files. We're working towards a 100% TS codebase which will enable us (amongst other things) to ship high-quality type definitions for TypeScript users.

### [`v3.0.0`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v3.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/compare/v2.1.1...v3.0.0)

#### Big changes

-   Chromium 81.0.4044.0 (r737027)
-   Puppeteer can now fetch a Firefox Nightly binary for you via `PUPPETEER_PRODUCT=firefox npm install`. Also, there‚Äôs now [an example](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/blob/master/examples/cross-browser.js) showing how to launch Firefox with Puppeteer.
-   File uploads are generally more reliable ([#​5363](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5363)) and `elementHandle.uploadFile(...filePaths)` now triggers a `change` event, matching the old behavior in Puppeteer v1.20.0. ([#​5389](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5389))
-   Node.js v8.x.x is no longer supported. ([#​5136](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5136))

#### Behind the scenes

-   Puppeteer is migrating to TypeScript. Although this doesn't affect the way developers can consume Puppeteer, it improves the quality of the Puppeteer type definitions which can be used by modern editors.
-   Our custom test runner framework has been removed in favor of Mocha, reducing maintenance overhead.
-   Our CI setup and the way we deal with test flakiness is being reworked in order to increase our confidence of landing PRs without breaking anything.

Issues.Title: Can't find type definitions for external module
Issues.Body:
Commands I used:
```
ng new test
npm i --save vss-web-extension-sdk 
```
After that I added into tsconfig.json:
```
"types": [ "vss-web-extension-sdk" ]
```
and updated angular.json with:
```
"scripts": [ "node_modules/vss-web-extension-sdk/lib/VSS.SDK.js" ]
```
per documentation at https://angular.io/guide/using-libraries#library-typings and https://angular.io/guide/typescript-configuration#typescript-typings that's all I have to do to make it work. So I just add usage like `VSS.init({});` into app.component.ts. But when I build it with
```
ng build
```
I'm facing an error:
```
src/app/app.component.ts:11:5 - error TS2304: Cannot find name 'VSS'.
11     VSS.init({});
```
I see that type definitions are presented in the module but ignored buy builder. I believe it's relaged to the [ambient module declaration](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/modules.html#ambient-modules) within vss-web-extension-sdk but not sure about that.
Angular CLI: 9.1.3
Node: 10.16.0
OS: win32 x64
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Can't find type definitions for external module" (#17558)

Issues.Title: "ng build -prod" is still extremely slow ÔºÅ
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description ng build --prod in a large project is extremely slow ! I found many issue to this problem,but in the end, they didn't solve it properly(search by keyword '92%'„ÄÅ'80%'„ÄÅ‚Äòslow‚Äô) It takes 11min at 7.x, 15min at 8.x, now it's too slow to be tolerated. I even wonder if angular can be used for large projects. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Large projects has this problems ## üî• Exception or Error 1„ÄÅ80% chunk modules optimization ModuleConcatenationPlugin 2„ÄÅ92% chunk asset optimization At this two points it takes so much time! I have two project created by @nrwl/nx. One has 256 files, it's build very fast with 3-5min. The other project has 2,598 files, it's build so slowly. Two projects share a lib (1000files) ng build without ivy and all config closed by false(aot„ÄÅbuildOptimizer...) need so many memory that jenkins server always crash.

Issues.Title: Webpack 5 Module Federation support
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request
Webpack 5 Module Federation API will be a game changer to the web. 
So bringing support to Angular CLI once Webpack 5 is released and supported will also be a game changer to Angular projects using the CLI. 

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
Once Angular CLI support Webpack 5 #17555 it is important to also support its new API called Module Federation that allow sharing modules in runtime among applications.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Support Webpack 5 Module Federation. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
No alternative considered.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Webpack 5 Module Federation support" (#17556)

Issues.Title: is-promise error with ng update
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... It's a regression in the underlying lib or rather angular didn't catch up with changes with the underlying lib. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... `ng update` fails because of npm package is-promise had an update and probably the update command didn't take versioning into consideration. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - have an angular 8 project - try upgrading with `ng update` ## üî• Exception or Error
``` ng update Your global Angular CLI version (9.1.3) is greater than your local version (8.3.20). The local Angular CLI version is used. To disable this warning use "ng config -g cli.warnings.versionMismatch false". The installed Angular CLI version is older than the latest stable version. Installing a temporary version to perform the update. Installing packages for tooling via npm. Installed packages for tooling via npm. Unknown error: Error [ERR_REQUIRE_ESM]: Must use import to load ES Module: /tmp/.ng-temp-packages-l4NeIR/node_modules/is-promise/index.js require() of ES modules is not supported. require() of /tmp/.ng-temp-packages-l4NeIR/node_modules/is-promise/index.js from /tmp/.ng-temp-packages-l4NeIR/node_modules/run-async/index.js is an ES module file as it is a .js file whose nearest parent package.json contains "type": "module" which defines all .js files in that package scope as ES modules. Instead rename /tmp/.ng-temp-packages-l4NeIR/node_modules/is-promise/index.js to end in .cjs, change the requiring code to use import(), or remove "type": "module" from /tmp/.ng-temp-packages-l4NeIR/node_modules/is-promise/package.json. ``` ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Karma with jsdom+custom shims/polyfills should create the right environment for the tests
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [X] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No, the previous mayor version (8.x.x) the issue was present as well. ### Description We are using `jsdom` as the target browser for unit testing in our Angular library. Our library uses the `crypto` API which is not implemented in `jsdom`, so we need a shim for this API. We did it as it's indicated in its docs: ```js const dom = new JSDOM(`

Hello

`, { beforeParse(window) { window.document.childNodes.length === 0; window.someCoolAPI = () => { /* ... */ }; } }); ``` Luckely the `karma-json-launcher` offers the posibility to configure the `jsdom` instance throught `karma.conf.js` file: ```js // karma.conf.js const jsdom = require("jsdom"); module.exports = function(config) { config.set({ browsers: ['jsdom'], jsdomLauncher: { jsdom: { beforeParse(window) { window.someCoolAPI = () => { /* ... */ }; } } } }); }; ``` The karma plugin creates the jsdom [instance correctly](https://github.com/badeball/karma-jsdom-launcher/blob/3c364d8988a7a1bc8d4687ec76810cb530adfffe/index.js#L28-L40) with the passed options, and it tries to parse the url where karma is running. But unfortunalety the `someCoolAPI` is not present in test context inside `window` property and test fails with a `ReferenceError: someCoolAPI is not defined` On the other hand, when you try to manually create your own `jsdom` instance (same way `karma-json-launcher does`), with `someCoolAPI` polyfill, and parse any html document which use that API inside it works, jsdom parses the document and the scripst are executed correctly, so that makes me think is not a `jsdom` or `karma-jsdom-launcher` problem. Can be an issue with the CLI, or Karma itself? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. ```sh $ ng new foo $ cd foo $ npm install karma-jsdom-launcher jsdom ``` 2. Configure `angular.json` file as @badeball indicates [here ](https://github.com/badeball/karma-jsdom-launcher#i-am-using-angular-cli-and-the-test-suite-hangs-indefinitely) due to #11561 and #13580 3. Configure `karma.config.js` file as `karma-jsdom-launcher` docs indicates: ```js // karma.config.js ... plugins: [ .... require('karma-jsdom-launcher'), .... ], ... browsers: ['jsdom'], jsdomLauncher: { jsdom: { beforeParse(window) { window.someCoolAPI = () => { /* ... */ }; } } }, ... ``` 4. Create `app.component.ts` that uses that `someCoolAPI` in some way. ``` @Component({...}) export class AppComponent { constructor() { window.someCoolAPI(); //the test will fail here because someCoolAPI is not defined } } ``` 5. ```sh ng test ``` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-list): properly render leading and trailing icons on list items
Issues.Body:
blocked on #19168

Note: I made some changes to the original list demo in this PR:
1. `mat-list-icon` and `mat-list-avatar` were pretty much 2 ways to do the same thing in the old version. In the new version, I'm positioning `mat-list-avatar` as the bigger leading icon style, and `mat-list-icon` as the smaller leading icon style (MDC supports both, and they call the larger one an "avatar", so this actually aligns well). I've changed the demo for the old version to show using `mat-list-icon` in a similar way.
2. One of the nav list demos was showing a not accessible pattern wit a trailing action button. I updated it to be a standard mat list instead of a nav list.

Issues.Title: build: dev-infra-private package not updating locally as expected
Issues.Body:
The dev-infra-private package sometimes is not updated
locally even if the integrity and SHA changed. This
seems to be because of a bug in yarn where the package
is restored from cache. A workaround seems to be using
the actual `.git` https URL.

See: https://github.com/yarnpkg/yarn/issues/4722.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: dev-infra-private package not updating locally as expected" (#19196)

Issues.Title: fix(datepicker): date range follow-up fixes
Issues.Body:
Contains the following fixes, split up into commits:

### fix(datepicker): calendar dispatching change event on non-user interactions
The calendar was changed to dispatch its `selectedChange` event for some non-user interactions. These changes restore the old behavior.

### fix(datepicker): unable to type in range inputs
In a previous fix I added some changes so that typing in an input counts as typing inside the entire date range input. The problem is that this causes some extra events to be fired which result in the user's typed value being overwritten as they're typing. These changes revert the previous fix and resolve the issue in a different way.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(datepicker): date range follow-up fixes" (#19198)

Issues.Title: fix(overlay): expand flexible origin type to allow SVG elements
Issues.Body:
The typing of the `FlexibleConnectedPositionStrategyOrigin` is scoped to `HTMLElement` which doesn't cover `SVGElement`, even though we support it. These changes update the type.

Note that this should be a safe change to the public API, because we're widening the type.

Fixes #36381.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(overlay): expand flexible origin type to allow SVG elements" (#19199)

Issues.Title: bug(dateRangePicker): model set value called multiple times on init
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

This is related to the pre-release date range picker

html:
<mat-form-field floatLabel="never">
    <mat-date-range-input [rangePicker]="dateRangePicker">
        <input matStartDate placeholder="Start date" [(ngModel)]="fromDate" />
        <input matEndDate placeholder="End date" [(ngModel)]="toDate" />
    </mat-date-range-input>
    <mat-datepicker-toggle [for]="dateRangePicker" matSuffix></mat-datepicker-toggle>
    <mat-date-range-picker #dateRangePicker></mat-date-range-picker>
</mat-form-field>
TypeScript:
private _to: Date;
private _from: Date;
set toDate(newDate: Date) {
  console.log("set to date");
  this._to = newDate;
}
get toDate(): Date {
  return this._to;
}
...etc.


Steps to reproduce:
1. Create range picker attaching models to the start and end date (partial code included)
2. Load page
 
 
#### Expected Behavior
What behavior were you expecting to see?

setters called once (maybe twice) during startup

#### Actual Behavior
What behavior did you actually see?

Set is called dozens (maybe hundreds?) of times.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.3
- CDK/Material: build from date-range branch
- Browser(s): FF
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  macOS 10.15.5

Issues.Title: bug(mat-button): Focus is barely perceptible on some buttons styles (accessibility issue)
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

StackBlitz demo: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-gvtqjt

Steps to reproduce:
1. Tab between each button
2. Notice the styles applied
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

A visible and clear indication of which element has been focused.


#### Actual Behavior

The `mat-raised-button` with no color, and the regular `mat-button`, have very clear style changes indicating they are focused. The `primary` raised button is _barely_ visible. Other button styles have visible changes but may not meet proposed contrast requirements.


#### Environment

- Angular: ^9.0.2
- CDK/Material: ^9.1.0 / 
- Browser(s): Firefox, Chrome, Edge
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows 10, MacOS Catalina


#### Notes

It may also be worth looking ahead to the proposed WCAG 2.2 guidelines, which have much clearer requirements regarding contrast. https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/focus-visible-enhanced

Issues.Title: bug([cdk/layout]): [addEventListener is undefined in iOS >=12]
Issues.Body:
I had issues loading my Angular 9 app on iPhone, it loads in all desktop browsers and android devices, just got an blank page in iPhone. It raised an promiseReactionJob exception .. running the lasted iOS version (13.4.1). I checked  index.html and the scripts are loaded as expected.
So, after isolate the problem, I identified that it was failing in the call below because addEventListener is undefined

    this.forMobileLandscapeAndDown.addEventListener('change', this.mediaQueryListener);

I checked the content of fem2015/layout.js and addEventListener does not exist in Safari for iOS.

The fix on my app was check the OS and call addListener instead of removeListener only for iOS.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.2
- CDK: 9.2.1
- Browser(s): Safari/Firefox/Chrome
- Operating System: iOS >= 12
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug([cdk/layout]): [addEventListener is undefined in iOS >=12]" (#19193)

Issues.Title: fix(datepicker): end input reset on load when bound through ngModel
Issues.Body: This is something I found while I was writing the live examples. When both the start and end inputs have an initial value bound through `ngModel`, the start resets the end, because the end's value wasn't yet defined at the time the start was assigning its value. These changes fix the issue by treating the entire input as a single unit when it comes to change events.

Issues.Title: fix(datepicker): clearing completed range when pressing escape

Issues.Body: Fixes a "changed after checked" error being thrown if the user has an active preview and they move to a different month using the keyboard. This is something that we had a fix for, but after #19088 it has to be moved one component up, because the binding that changes is in a different view.

Issues.Title: fix(menu): clicks on disabled item closing the menu
Issues.Body:
We have some logic to prevent clicks on disabled items from closing the menu. The problem is that browsers swallow clicks and don't fire their event listeners for disabled `button` nodes, but not any non-disabled child nodes. In #16696 we made it consistent so clicks don't land on any of the button's elements, but these changes fix the underlying issue by binding the event both on the root `button`, and a wrapper `span` that's around the content. This way we're guaranteed to hit at least one of the listeners.

These changes also move the event outside the `NgZone` since it doesn't trigger any changes in the view.

Fixes #19173.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(menu): clicks on disabled item closing the menu" (#19183)

Issues.Title: fix(list): selection list marked as touched when tabbing in
Issues.Body:
In #18445 the selection list was changed so that it moves focus to the first item when the list receives focus. The problem is that the logic that marks it as touched was still using the list's `blur` event which means that it'll be marked as touched when focus goes from the list to the item. These changes switch to only using the `blur` event on the item.

Fixes #19171.

Issues.Title: fr(table): Add column name to CellHarnessFilters
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Currently, when we want to get a `MatCellHarness` with a column name `key` we would write:

`await loader.getHarness(MatCellHarness.with({selector: '.mat-column-key'}));`

as we have not found any other suitable way. It would be great if we could use the `with` static method and search using a `column` option such as:

`await loader.getHarness(MatCellHarness.with({column: 'key'}));`

#### Use Case

The consumer of the `MatCellHarness` should not be aware of the class prefix `mat-column-` that is added in a column from the library itself.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "fr(table): Add column name to CellHarnessFilters" (#19172)
